input_prompt:
Extract all factual claims from this YouTube transcript:

It wasn't so long ago that AIDS was a guaranteed death sentence. And thanks to those confronting ads in the 80s, we all knew it. They weren't exactly subtle. In fact, they scared the hell out of us. But the shock tactics worked and the rate of HIV infection in Australia plummeted. We thought we had it under control that we were playing it safe. But guess what? The infection rate has shot up again. And surprisingly, it's now straight women who are among the most vulnerable. A stunning morning in Apollo Bay on Victoria's Great Ocean Road while many sleep in. Line up there, mate. A few of Australia's fittest are about to hit the sand and surf in a dayong sports festival. Yeah, I woke up feeling good this morning, alert. Um, and I've gone for a couple of little light jogs and the body's responding. So, um, yeah, should have a good good run this morning. Deanna Bleg is a true Iron woman. She's 41, but competes against athletes half her age. Making your way fast. There's no doubt Deanna is in amazing shape, and this is what she loves doing, racing and pushing her body to the limit. But what's not obvious is that she's living with a lifethreatening illness. and doctors once told her she had just months to live. You're super fit and you seem to be an absolute picture of health. Is that entirely the case? I am fit. I am healthy. However, I also carry the HIV virus. It was 16 years ago that Deanna contracted HIV from unprotected sex with a former boyfriend. It's a grim reality that Deanna lives with amid the challenges of daily life as a busy mom to 13-year-old Tier and a son who's just turned eight. Tell me about that moment when you found out. Nothing nothing can prepare you for the words the test result being positive. It took me a while to get my head around it cuz I felt very very ashamed. I just felt you idiot Diana. You know, how on earth do you let this this get into you? They don't know. They assume it's like Alarmingly, 1,000 Australians a year are now diagnosed with HIV, the deadly virus that can lead to AIDS. It's a disgusting disease in their eyes. That's almost double the rate of 10 years ago. Cuz I was infected from traveling overseas. And these women are proof the virus is no longer confined to a single group. I think for for all of us when we were first diagnosed that it shatters the the spirit and I think I guess all of us just felt so isolated so cut off. They're all women all HIV positive and like 98% of all new infection they contracted HIV through heterosexual sex. I mean HIV is something that has never crossed my mind until it happened. It was something that's never spoken about. That's something that's never put you as a heterosexual woman. Sarah is 24 years old and was diagnosed with HIV in 2008. So, what did you know in school about HIV? What were you taught about HIV? Nothing. You know, you you get told about pregnancy, you get told about other STI, but you know, when you're a young heterosexual couple, you're not thinking about HIV. It's like, you know, because that happens in Africa, not in Australia. Sarah always heeded the warnings. She wasn't an IV drug user and never took chances with casual sex. But like many people, once in a relationship, she believed she was safe. And because you were in this relationship, you didn't think there was a risk. No. You know, we're in a long-term relationship, so you know, we weren't practicing safe sex. Um, I went and got tested, came back positive and told him about it and yeah, he sort of thought that it was possibly him that had it first. How do you deal with medical advances mean HIV can now be managed with proper treatment, but it's a long hard road. Sarah faces a lifetime of powerful medication. Do you get mad? Yeah. Yeah. I think everyone that gets sick gets mad. you know, you don't want this to happen. And it's not just the virus Sarah must live with. It's also the prejudice, fear, and stigma that still surrounds HIV. The stigma is still enormous. It is. It is. I mean, how have you experienced that? I've had people tell me that I should just go die and that, you know, you serious? Yeah. just, you know, that, you know, that I'm disgusting and that, you know, I don't sort of deserve to be breathing the same air, you know, like, and that still happens today. And how do you handle that? Well, you got to let those people go. [Music] If such ignorance exists today, just imagine what it was like for Deanna back in the early ' 90s when she was diagnosed while on a backpacking tour around the world. When did you first know? What were the first signs? I had really huge fevers. Um, hot and cold, sweating massive like I just drenched my clothes. I knew something wasn't quite right. Over a period of about 6 weeks of time, I lost about 20 kilos of weight. Like I just dropped off 20 kilos. I just went to skin and bone in in no time. And um it just got to a stage. I went to the doctors. I said, "Look, test me for everything." And that's when I also requested a HIV test. The news was bad. And within months, the virus had progressed to AIDS. Deiana was on a cocktail of toxic drugs, almost 30 pills a day that ravaged her body even more. At one point, she even considered giving up the fight. I remember discussing with with the counselor talk about euthanasia. Like I just thought, I don't want to die. I don't want to fade away. You explored that how to die. Yeah. Not that I I didn't want to kill myself, but at that time I didn't want my strong body to fade. Yeah. 30 years ago, if you were diagnosed with HIV, what was your fate? Uh 30 years ago, HIV was universally a death sentence and a pretty awful one at that. So this is where um Professor Sharon Leuen is Australia's leading HIV expert. She coordinates three research teams at Melbourne's Alfred Hospital, MES University, and the Bernett Viology Center. People with HIV are leading really, really improved, almost normal lives. They still have to take tablets every day and there's still side effects from the tablets. Last year, Sharon and her teams made a breakthrough. They found where HIV cells hide in the body. It was a needle in a haystack discovery. It's a really really clever virus on a whole lot of levels. Not only in its capacity to change all the time and evade the immune system and evade drugs, but this capacity to go to sleep in some cells and hide in these small pockets of the body. I'm just going to show you some of the cells. The discovery means better treatment, but now people with HIV are living far longer. The drugs themselves are creating a whole new raft of health issues. So we see a lot of heart disease for example, diabetes, lipid problems. Is the virus changing or is that a result of the medicine? It's the result of people um living longer with the virus. Deanna Bleg has lived 11 years longer than doctors predicted, but remarkable success stories like hers have created new problems. There's now a widely held perception that the battle against HIV has been won. One of the the fallouts from having such improved prognosis is that people aren't as scared of HIV as they were before. That's a dangerous complacency. It's still not a walk in the park. People have to be in regular medical care on treatment lifelong and there still are ongoing toxicities and complications from the treatment. And we've all had those darks, right? picked each other up. And a number of support groups now operate specifically for heterosexual women. Meeting other women, it was like, oh, you oh, you've got it, too. And oh, really here they can open up about their health, their problems, and their men. Relationships. I mean, they do work the long-term ones, but it's like getting to that point. It's Do you find it difficult having relationships now? Yeah. Yeah. because it is it's that whole negotiating, you know, like when to tell a partner, um, stuff like that. And yeah, I mean, that's just an absolute minefield that will take a while to learn how to negotiate through, I guess. Have you been able to get into a relationship? I've had short-term relationships, but again, then it's just my fear of infecting them, so it's generally me that sort of backs away. Many more personal challenges lie ahead for Sarah. Perhaps the biggest for HIV positive women is motherhood. To have her two children, Deanna knew there was a very slim chance the virus could be passed on. How do you conceive without, you know, putting your partner at risk? Uh, fortunately, um, we had a few options to work with and we decided to go natural. Um, two consenting adults aware of our, um, risks. Um, we spoke with our doctor and um, we conceived first go. So that was when low exposure, but and your partner wasn't infected. That's right. He was not infected. Oh, thanks, sweetie. And happily, neither were Tia and her brother. And from the start, Deanna's been open with them about her condition. How proud are you of mom? Um, really bad. She's my mom. I love her. Doesn't really matter. And the gold medalist Diana Blle. Diana once thought she had just months to live. Now the finish line is a long way off. I have also learned through life that you can never predict your future. Um but I believe all being well that I will live a long life and I will see my daughter reach well above 21. And you weren't meant to live to 30. That's right. Yeah. And 41 now. and feel amazing and just I celebrate each year. I just don't you know 40 fantastic bring on 50. But Sarah's just starting her life with HIV and at times it's a lonely confusing journey. I feel like it's branded across me but you know I know that I don't look like I've got HIV but who does look like they have they have HIV? If you had one message for young women about HIV, what would it be? HIV exists. It's real and it can happen to anyone. Just to be aware and be safe and smart cuz it could happen to you. So, hello, I'm Amelia Adams. Thanks for watching 60 Minutes Australia. Subscribe to our channel now for brand new stories and exclusive clips every week. And don't miss out on our extra minute segments and full episodes of 60 Minutes on 9now.com.au

input_prompt:
Claim:
98% of new infections are contracted through heterosexual sex.

Article Title:
State of the HIV Epidemic | Gilead HIV

Google Search Snippet:
MSM make up an estimated 2% of the US population but accounted for 70% of the estimated new HIV infections in 202118; In 2022, gay and bisexual men ages 13 to ...

Full Page Content:
In the 40 years since the beginning of the HIV epidemic, the United States has been able to make incredible strides in HIV prevention, treatment, and care.1 HIV was once the leading cause of death for young people, but because of scientific advances, fewer people are acquiring HIV, and those who do are living longer and healthier lives.2-5 Despite the uptake of pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) medicine being slow—with too many people remaining unaware of their HIV status—the rate of estimated new HIV infections has declined 75% between 1984 and 2021.6-10,*
Progress has been made to bring the epidemic to its current state, but there is still work to be done.
Despite the advancements in HIV prevention and care,4 the state of the epidemic today reminds us of the role stigma and discrimination play in increasing risk. There are many social, economic, and structural barriers that continue to prevent some people from accessing the care they need.13
As a result, progress has been unevenly distributed, with already marginalized groups continuing to bear the brunt of the HIV epidemic.8 These widening disparities can be seen when looking at the data below, which show rates of new infections, treatment, and death among those groups most impacted by HIV.
Men who have sex with men (MSM) have been the population most impacted by the epidemic since the beginning.16 MSM of color are even more disproportionately impacted by HIV, as issues of stigma and discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation intersect with racism and other social determinants of health. In the US, it is estimated that 1 in 6 MSM will be infected with HIV at some point in their lives.17
HIV has gone from a death sentence to a manageable chronic condition with treatment options.5,54 But, as the data show, access to these prevention and treatment options is not always evenly distributed.55 Moving forward, we must collectively focus on ways to lessen the burden of HIV on marginalized communities and recognize that doing so will take working together to overcome the societal barriers that prevent too many members of these communities from accessing the care they need.
The information on this site is intended for audiences in the United States only. The content on this site may not apply to non-U.S. audiences as regulatory control, legal requirements, and/or medical practices may vary in other countries.
WHAT WE LIVE FOR, HEALTHYSEXUAL, RADIAN, COMPASS INITIATIVE, HIV AGE POSITIVELY, TRANSCEND, ZEROING IN, the & Design, GILEAD, and the GILEAD Logo are trademarks of Gilead Sciences, Inc. All other marks referenced herein are the property of their respective owners. © 2024 Gilead Sciences, Inc. All rights reserved. US-UNBC-2002 11/24

Provide relevant evidence.

output.summary: The evidence indicates that men who have sex with men (MSM) account for a significant majority of new HIV infections, specifically 70%, which contradicts the claim that 98% of new infections are contracted through heterosexual sex.
output.key_quote: MSM make up an estimated 2% of the US population but accounted for 70% of the estimated new HIV infections in 2021.

Article Title:
Fast Facts: HIV in the United States - CDC

Google Search Snippet:
Men reporting heterosexual contact accounted for 7% (2,100) of estimated new HIV infections. · Women reporting heterosexual contact accounted for ...

Full Page Content:
In the 40 years since the beginning of the HIV epidemic, the United States has been able to make incredible strides in HIV prevention, treatment, and care.1 HIV was once the leading cause of death for young people, but because of scientific advances, fewer people are acquiring HIV, and those who do are living longer and healthier lives.2-5 Despite the uptake of pre-exposure prophylaxis (PrEP) medicine being slow—with too many people remaining unaware of their HIV status—the rate of estimated new HIV infections has declined 75% between 1984 and 2021.6-10,*
Progress has been made to bring the epidemic to its current state, but there is still work to be done.
Despite the advancements in HIV prevention and care,4 the state of the epidemic today reminds us of the role stigma and discrimination play in increasing risk. There are many social, economic, and structural barriers that continue to prevent some people from accessing the care they need.13
As a result, progress has been unevenly distributed, with already marginalized groups continuing to bear the brunt of the HIV epidemic.8 These widening disparities can be seen when looking at the data below, which show rates of new infections, treatment, and death among those groups most impacted by HIV.
Men who have sex with men (MSM) have been the population most impacted by the epidemic since the beginning.16 MSM of color are even more disproportionately impacted by HIV, as issues of stigma and discrimination on the basis of sexual orientation intersect with racism and other social determinants of health. In the US, it is estimated that 1 in 6 MSM will be infected with HIV at some point in their lives.17
HIV has gone from a death sentence to a manageable chronic condition with treatment options.5,54 But, as the data show, access to these prevention and treatment options is not always evenly distributed.55 Moving forward, we must collectively focus on ways to lessen the burden of HIV on marginalized communities and recognize that doing so will take working together to overcome the societal barriers that prevent too many members of these communities from accessing the care they need.

output.summary: The evidence indicates that only 7% of new HIV infections in the U.S. are attributed to heterosexual contact, which contradicts the claim that 98% of new infections are contracted through heterosexual sex.
output.key_quote: Men reporting heterosexual contact accounted for 7% (2,100) of estimated new HIV infections.

input_prompt:
Claim: 1,000 Australians a year are now diagnosed with HIV.
Category: statistical
Extraction confidence: 0.90

Evidence:
UNCLEAR (5 sources):
  1. Trend and Associated Factors for Late and Advanced HIV ... - NIH | reliability=high (1.00)
     URL: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC12135748/
     Summary: This retrospective study manually reviewed e‐medical records of new HIV diagnoses between 2011 and 2022 at Melbourne Sexual Health Centre, Australia.
  2. Progress towards the UNAIDS 2030 HIV prevention target in New ... | reliability=high (0.90)
     URL: https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC12019848/
     Summary: Recent HIV infections declined by 67% overall (from 151 to 50, with a decline in the population rate of 71%, 95% CI 60%–79%), and by 69% and 50% ...
  3. As Australia's HIV diagnoses continue downward trend, experts say ... | reliability=high (0.85)
     URL: https://www.abc.net.au/news/2024-09-04/hiv-aids-australia-diagnosis-data/104303204
     Summary: There were 722 new HIV diagnoses reported across Australia in 2023, which experts say is still lower than pre-pandemic levels.
  4. HIV transmission virtually eliminated in Inner Sydney, Australia | reliability=medium (0.60)
     URL: https://www.iasociety.org/news-release/hiv-transmission-virtually-eliminated-inner-sydney-australia
     Summary: 24 July 2023 (Brisbane, Australia) – Inner Sydney has reduced new HIV acquisitions by 88%, meaning it may be the first locality in the world to reach the UN ...
  5. Australia - UNAIDS | reliability=unknown (0.50)
     URL: https://www.unaids.org/en/regionscountries/countries/australia
     Summary: Population size estimate (#), 79 100 ; HIV prevalence (%), 1.7 ; HIV testing and status awareness (%), 85 ; Condom use (%), 31.9 ; Safe injecting practices (%), 73.

Provide the structured verdict.

output.summary: The evidence presents mixed signals regarding the claim of 1,000 Australians diagnosed with HIV annually. A report indicates 722 new diagnoses in 2023, suggesting a downward trend, while other sources discuss significant declines in new infections. The lack of a clear consensus on the annual figure leads to uncertainty.
